definition:
Let $E\subset {\mathbf R}^n$ be a measurable set. We define the
*essential boundary* of $E$ as
$$\partial^* E := \{x\in{\mathbf R}^n\colon 0 < | E\cap B_\rho(x)| < |B_\rho(x)|,\quad \forall \rho>0\}$$
where $|\cdot|$ is the Lebesgue measure.

Compare the definition of $\partial^* E$ with the definition of the
topological boundary $\partial E$ which can be written as
$$\partial E = \{ x \in {\mathbf R}^n \colon \emptyset \subsetneq E\cap B_\rho(x) \subsetneq B_\rho(x),\quad \forall \rho>0\}.$$
Hence one clearly has $\partial^* E\subset \partial E$.

Notice that the essential boundary does not depend on the Lebesgue
representative of the set $E$, in the sense that if $|E\triangle F|=0$
then $\partial^* E = \partial ^* F$. For example if
$E=\mathbf Q^n\subset {\mathbf R}^n$ is the set of points with rational
coordinates, one has $\partial^* E=\emptyset$ while
$\partial E={\mathbf R}^n$.

Nevertheless one can easily prove that $\partial^*E$ is always a closed
set (in the usual sense).
